Hi Jon,

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jon S Bratseth [mailto:Jon.Bratseth@...]
> Sent: 30 October 2002 11:50
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Testing a class inside an Application Server
> 
> Why people think running a test inside a server is related to servlets
is
> beyond me. 

Me too. Who said that? ;-)

> A much simpler approach is to create a test case extension
> which
> delegates it's execution to a session bean.

Why is it simpler? That's exactly Cactus's approach! :-). ATM cactus
only provides Filter, Servlet and Jsp extensions but we are working on
providing EJB redirectors (session beans, MDB, EB). I would love to be
able to work with you on that if you're interested! It seems we could
easily integrate your solution in Cactus :-)

BTW, most person call their EJB from a Web layer and thus it makes sense
for them to use the ServletTestCase to write their unit test as the test
is then more similar to production. But I agree that's not the only use
case which is why I am very keen to have the EJB redirectors implemented
in Cactus!

> 
> There is a package which provides this at
> http://www.junit.org/junit/download/ServerTestCase.zip

cool. Maybe we can join forces.

> 
> To use it, just deploy the session bean and extends ServerTestCase
instead
> of TestCase for tests you want to run inside the server.

Cool. Again, that's exactly in the same way as Cactus does it.

> 
> The tests will behave like the client/standalone tests, so there will
only
> be one test suite to manage and there's no need to re-create all the
> features mentioned below specially for the server-side tests.
> 

Yes, but I don't see how you test your web layer with your solution. If
I remember correctly that was what I was answering to :-). In any case
you don't need to care as Cactus is hiding this for you. EJBs are
well-defined components and as such are much easier to unit test than
web components. Actually if you have remote EJBs, you don't even need to
have a session bean redirector, which is even simpler ... :-)

> ...Yeah, I know I'm lagging somewhat  :-)

I don't think so :-)

-Vincent
> 
> --
> Jon S Bratseth
> 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Vincent Massol [mailto:vmassol@...]

> >
> >
> > Hi Michael,
> >
> > <biased>
> >
> > How different is what you have described from
> > http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/1.4/howto_tomcat.html ?
> >
> > Actually, what you described is exactly JUnitEE
> > (http://junitee.sourceforge.net/).
> >
> > I agree with you, it starts simple and then you need some more
features.
> > For example, you need to automate the tests as part of a build (this
is
> > probably one of the most wanted feature). So you will start to have
a
> > client part that calls your URL, parses the XML and display the
result.
> > All is fine but then you also want to be able to execute the test
from
> > any of the existing JUnit integration tools (from IDEs, using Ant
junit
> > task, etc). So you will transform your client side into a TestCase
so
> > that it can be run by any test runner ...
> >
> > ... and this is Cactus ! :-)
> >
> > To summarise :
> >
> > - yes Cactus can be a simple as what you describe (this is actually
a
> > feature of version 1.4, which is not released yet - but soon to be)
> >
> > - it allow for more should you need it
> >
> > - it is documented and there are resources on Cactus : website +
books +
> > articles
> >
> > - BTW, Cactus integrates completely with Ant to automated start up
and
> > shutdown of application servers
> >
> > </biased>
> >
> > Yes, I am the original author of Cactus and thus I am biased :-) but
as
> > a user I would always go with existing framework if I find any that
> > perform what I want. For example, I wouldn't dare write my logging
> > framework, MVC controller one, XML to Java mapping one, etc.
> >
> > In the end it is your choice. I'm just writing this email so that
you
> > know Cactus does what you want and that you shouldn't skip it
because
> > you think it doesn't.
> >
> > Cheers,
> > -Vincent
> >

to
> > plug
